title: Can hypnotism be induced in non-hysterical subjects?
first_phrase: This is the last part of an article discussing the controversial idea that only hysterical or neurotic individuals can be hypnotized. The author cites several experts who argue that this is a misconception and that people of any age or background can be susceptible to hypnotic suggestion. In particular, Donato's observations and results demonstrate that there is no marked difference in sensitivity between men and women. The author concludes that the complex nature of hypnotic phenomena demands patient, careful, and scrupulous study, and that unfounded biases and assumptions must be abandoned in order to accurately understand the nature of hypnotism.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the study of magnetic science has seen numerous developments over the years, with the doctrine of Mesmer divided into the medicine of magnets and human magnetism. The classification of different phenomena associated with magnetic science remains broad and highly debated among various experts. However, it is essential to approach any conclusions on these phenomena with great caution. The study of somnambulism, in particular, has led to different interpretations of the facts. Nonetheless, there is no denying that magnetic science has contributed significantly to various fields, from electrotherapy to psychophysiology and beyond.
